content:
• Monday, December 14, 2015
  • WDR

    Asset managers punished in high-yield selloff

    • Like stocks, junk bonds finished well off their worst levels of the session, but unlike equities, junk still gave up sizable ground for the day.
    • Not only are investors losing confidence in lower-quality paper, they're also unloading the companies that most actively deal in the paper.
    • Waddell & Reed (NYSE:WDR) - whose $6.2B Ivy High Income Fund (MUTF:WHIAX) has suffered the largest outflows this year of any junk-bond fund - fell 7.5% today, and nearly 15% over the past week.
    • The manager of the $5.8B AB High Income Advisor Fund, AllianceBernstein (NYSE:AB) tumbled 7.1% on the session, and major Third Avenue Management investor Affiliated Managers Group (NYSE:AMG) brought its two-day decline to more than 13% with a 5.8% fall today.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:27 PM | 2 Comments
  • LL

    Lumber Liquidators up 17.4% after Tilson covers short

    • Whitney Tilson, who first disclosed a short position in Lumber Liquidators (NYSE:LL) in late 2013, says he has covered.
    • Tilson: "In the past week, I’ve received information that leads me to believe that senior management of Lumber Liquidators wasn’t aware that the company was selling Chinese-made laminate that had high levels of formaldehyde ... If there are no 'smoking gun' documents/emails, then the doomsday scenario for the company (and the stock) is less likely, so I covered my short position today."
    • He adds that if Lumber Liquidators' management "didn't have evil intent," downside scenarios are less likely and upside scenarios more likely. "This shift in the risk/reward equation has led me to cover my short position (for tax reasons, I have done so by buying in-the-money ($10 strike) call options expiring next month; I expect to close out these offsetting positions in the new year)."
    • Lumber Liquidators' beaten-down shares have jumped to $16.50 after hours.
     
     
     
     
    | 6:18 PM | 38 Comments
  • SBGI

    Report: Congress to ease pending local broadcast ownership restrictions

    • Observers say discussions on Capitol Hill are going well for broadcasters looking for more station ownership freedom.
    • Restrictions are in development on broadcasters' ability to control more than one TV station in a given city. But representatives from both parties are supporting leaving alone some joint arrangements that predated tougher rules from the FCC, Bloomberg reports.
    • The regulators had taken action to limit station owners controlling the advertising of nearby stations owned by another. Some 85 such arrangements had been approved by the agency from 2008 to last year.
    • Execs from Sinclair Broadcast Group (SBGI -2.1%), the nation's biggest local broadcaster, and Nexstar (NXST -2.9%) have been updating investors with expectations that lawmakers would roll back some of the onerous parts of the restrictions.
    • The language related to broadcast ownership would be attached to a spending bill on which Congress is trying to beat a Dec. 16 deadline -- which would ease matters for broadcasters who would have to comply with the new duopoly rules next year.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:43 PM

  • After Hours Gainers / Losers

    • Top gainers, as of 5.25 p.m.: TVIX +3.6%. CLLS +2.6%. VIIX +1.7%. AMGN +1.3%. SHPG +1.2%.
    • Top losers, as of 5.25p.m.: ARWR -5.6%. PAY -3.1%. BCS -3.0%. VZ -2.5%. PLAY -2.4%.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:41 PM | 7 Comments
  • HBAYF

    Hudson's Bay near $250M deal for Gilt Groupe

    • Saks Fifth Avenue owner Hudson's Bay (OTCPK:HBAYF -3.9%) is nearing a deal to buy luxury online seller Gilt Groupe for $250M, The Wall Street Journal reports, with an eye to combining it with its Off 5th outlet business.
    • That's significantly lower than a valuation for Gilt of $1.1B assumed in 2011. Talks are preliminary and a final deal hasn't been struck.
    • Gilt has raised more than $300M since its 2007 founding.
    • Previously: Hudson's Bay announces strategic realignment (Sep. 29 2015)
     
     
     
     
    | 5:34 PM
  • XRX

    Icahn bumps Xerox stake up to 8.13%

    • In a 13D filing, Carl Icahn and his investment vehicles report boosting his stake in Xerox (XRX -1.8%) to 8.13%, from a previous 7.13%.
    • His amended filing puts the group's ownership at 83.31M shares of an outstanding 1.012B.
    • Icahn disclosed a 7.13% stake late last month along with statements that he intended to talk performance with management, including strategic alternatives. The investment made Icahn the company's No. 2 shareholder.
    • Xerox shares are up 0.6% after hours.
    • Previously: Icahn discloses 7.1% stake in Xerox; shares +8.7% (Nov. 23 2015)
     
     
     
     
    | 5:27 PM | 6 Comments
  • CBB

    Cincinnati Bell closes offering of CyrusOne shares for $48M

    • Cincinnati Bell (CBB -3.7%) has closed a secondary offering of its stock in CyrusOne (CONE -1%), for net proceeds of about $47.6M.
    • The company offered 1.35M shares. After the offering, Cincinnati Bell maintains about a 9.5% stake in the data center operator through common and exchangeable shares.
    • CyrusOne has been gradually buying its way out of its relationship with Cincinnati Bell through a number of transactions.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:15 PM | 4 Comments
  • KMT

    Kennametal lowers guidance, citing weakening end market conditions

    • Kennametal (NYSE:KMT) -21.8% AH after warning that it expects as much as a 30%-60% decrease in previously announced guidance for FY 2016 adjusted EPS, citing expectations of lower revenue and the current lack of visibility to its end markets.
    • KMT says revenue expectations have been hurt by further declines in its end markets as evidenced by continued declines in industrial production indexes since its November guidance, particularly China automotive and U.S. and China coal mining, as well as further reductions in oil and gas activity.
    • Current analyst consensus estimates predict a 14% Y/Y decline in revenues of to $2.28B and a 26% Y/Y decline in EPS to $1.50.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:07 PM
  • FTR

    Frontier taking on $160M in costs to settle with West Virginia

    • Frontier Communications (FTR -1.5%) is settling a dispute with the state of West Virginia in a deal for $160M.
    • After receiving complaints, state authorities had charged the company with false advertising and poor broadband performance. The company's service of up to 6 Mbps was slow or failed entirely, customers had told the state.
    • Frontier will pay the state $500K for costs in the probe, and drop the fee on its 6-Mbps tier down to $10/month (from between $20 and $30) until it can provide the advertised speeds.
    • It will also spend $150M on capital improvements in the state.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:58 PM
  • APPS

    Digital Turbine adjusts guidance due to later launches

    • Digital Turbine (APPS -7.4%) now expects fiscal 2016 revenue to fall between $90M and $100M, the company said in an update to its guidance for next year.
    • The firm points to changes to timing in device launches; many recently added distribution partners will now launch in the first quarter of fiscal 2017 rather than in fiscal 2016 (ending in March), while other partners will be on board later in Q4 than expected.
    • As for the current quarter (fiscal Q3), the ad business should drive second-half revenue growth of up to 200% sequentially from a $7.3M first-half total. The company says yield per device is trending over its target of $2.
    • Shares were flat in after-hours trading.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:47 PM | 2 Comments
  • BA

    Boeing raises buyback program to $14B, raises dividend 20%

    • Boeing (BA -1.1%) is up 0.9% after hours following a move to bump its dividend 20%, and an increase in its repurchase authorization to $14B total.
    • Some $5.25B had remained on the company's prior buyback authorization, which was for $12B last December. This year's buybacks are complete after Boeing repurchased $6.75B.
    • The new $14B authorization replaces the former one, and the company expects to resume buybacks in January.
    • The dividend increase marks the fifth straight year with a raise.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:23 PM | 21 Comments
  • PAY

    VeriFone Systems beats by $0.01, beats on revenue

    • VeriFone Systems (NYSE:PAY): FQ4 EPS of $0.49 beats by $0.01.
    • Revenue of $514.1M (+4.8% Y/Y) beats by $0.67M.
    • Shares +2%.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:04 PM
  • CHK

    Chesapeake Energy hires adviser to probe options, including debt exchange

    • Chesapeake Energy (CHK -4.3%) is working with restructuring advisers at Evercore on potential measures to reduce its $11.6B debt load, such as exchanging existing bonds at a discount for new securities or selling assets, Dow Jones reports.
    • CHK bonds, considered a junk bond benchmark because of the company's large debt load, are tumbling today, with a 2019 bond down $0.02 to $0.30.
    • The tumble in natural gas prices has hurt CHK, which has posted three straight quarterly losses this year.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:43 PM | 33 Comments
  • S

    Sprint -3.6%, absorbing another new chief of marketing

    • Sprint (NYSE:S) is off 3.6% and still hanging in December doldrums after the company this weekend named its third chief marketing officer in less than a year and a half.
    • Roger Solé is taking over for Kevin Crull, who will lead one of the four geographic regions in the carrier's new organizational structure. Crull had assumed the position in May.l
    • Solé had joined Sprint from Brazil's TIM Participaçöes, and was leading Sprint's efforts in acquisition marketing and marketing to the carrier's Hispanic customers.
    • Among Sprint's struggles with cash burn and customer acquisition, marketing has been unsettled in the past 18 months as it has rapidly changed approaches and campaigns in an effort to stem losses.
    • Shares have fallen 20% since hitting $4.46 on Nov. 18.
    • Previously: Sprint restructuring: Four regional hubs, uniting sales channels (Nov. 13 2015)
     
     
     
     
    | 3:39 PM | 28 Comments
  • CRMD

    CorMedix's late stage Neutrolin study underway; shares rise 18%

    • Thinly traded nano cap CorMedix (CRMD +18.2%) is up on triple normal volume in response to its announcement that the first patient has been dosed in its Phase 3 clinical trial, LOCK-IT-100, assessing Fast Track- and QIDP-tagged Neutrolin in preventing catheter-related bloodstream infections (CRBSIs) in patients with end stage renal disease receiving hemodialysis.
    • The primary endpoint of the 633-subject, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, active control study is freedom from CRBSIs, specifically Neutrolin's superiority in preventing CRBSIs compared to active control (the blood thinner heparin) or normal control (saline).
    • In the U.S., there are 250K CRBSIs each year with mortality rates of 20 - 25%.
    • Neutrolin, a novel formulation of the antimicrobial agent taurolidine, citrate (salt) and heparin, keeps catheters operating safely and effectively by decreasing the risk of infection, thrombosis and biofilm formation. It is CE Mark cleared in Europe but not yet approved in the U.S.
    • Previously: CorMedix gaps up 14% on FDA guidance that beefs up late-stage Neutrolin trial (June 17)
     
     
     
     
    | 3:39 PM | 9 Comments
  • CEQP

    Crestwood Equity Partners +17% as fund suggests ways to enhance value

    • Crestwood Equity Partners (CEQP +16.9%) is skyrocketing after activist hedge fund Raging Capital Management's letter to the company's board details its "Crestwood comeback" program, including a reduced distribution that would improve the coverage ratio and a substantial direct unit buyback program.
    • Even at a $3.50/unit annual distribution - a ~35% reduction from current levels - CEQP still would have a 25% yield at current prices, a ~1.5x coverage ratio and substantial excess cash flows that would allow the company to repurchase units, Raging Capital says.
    • The hedge fund views CEQP as a "unique MLP with... scarce and/or strategically advantaged assets with a $4B-plus enterprise value" whose units are undervalued "due to a combination of technical factors and several fundamental misunderstandings."
    • Presentation
     
     
     
     
    | 3:30 PM | 7 Comments
  • OXM

    Oxford Industries battles back

    • Oxford Industries (NYSE:OXM) picks itself up off the floor today with a 4.6% swing higher.
    • Shares of the apparel company have been struggling most of the year, capped off with last week's dip after FQ3 numbers were released.
    • During the earnings call, Oxford execs noted that the Tommy Bahama and Lilly Pulitzer brands are comping positive for FQ4 so far.
    • Oxford Industries earnings call transcript
     
     
     
     
    | 3:21 PM
  • BA

    Boeing 787s blacklisted by Australian agency for location data flaw

    • A new problem has surfaced for the Boeing (BA -1.6%) 787 Dreamliner: Most of the planes that have been delivered to customers suffer from a software glitch that has caused at least five of the planes to report erroneous location data to air traffic control, prompting two Australian air traffic management agencies to put the 787 on a blacklist for some services.
    • According to a recent report from FlightGlobal.com, 787s currently rolling off the assembly line do not have the problem; BA says the software problem does not pose a safety hazard, and a service bulletin with instructions for operators to correct the error will be released "imminently.”
     
     
     
     
    | 3:21 PM | 11 Comments
  • BAS

    Basic Energy Services maintains guidance for 13%-15% lower Q4 revenues

    • Basic Energy Services (BAS -13%) tumbles to all-time lows after reiterating its recent guidance forecasting a 13%-15% Q/Q drop in Q4 revenue.
    • BAS says well servicing rig utilization rates also continued to decline during November to 37.6K hours, or ~39%, down from 44% in October and 67% in November 2014; drill rig utilization was 16% last month, edging up from 13% pace in October but down drastically from 83% a year ago.
    • Shares are downgraded to Sector Perform from Outperform at Scotia Howard Weil.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:58 PM | 4 Comments
  • SQ

    Square gains after IPO underwriters launch coverage, talk up newer services

    • Square (SQ +2.5%) has received bullish ratings from Barclays, Goldman, Jefferies, JPMorgan, and RBC on underwriter coverage day, to go with neutral ratings from Deutsche, Morgan Stanley, and Stifel.
    • Goldman's James Schneider ($16 target) argues Square "can sustain its strong growth by continuing to expand and monetize its footprint of [2M+] SMB merchants," and is also upbeat about new offerings such as the Square Capital SMB lending service. "[W]e think the company will begin to achieve meaningful scale in Square Capital (we forecast $2.3bn of originations in 2018) and software solutions (we model $40mn in SaaS revenue in 2018)." He sees margins improving (and Square's heavy losses narrowing) as the company's investment pace slows.
    • RBC's Daniel Perlin ($15 target): "Square has developed a suite of solutions that allows the company to: (a) address more of an SMB’s needs; (b) integrate itself more closely with the merchant; (c) increase the revenue and margin opportunity (discussed below); and (d) improve/maintain retention rates. We believe that the suite set is a significant driver of the company’s average retention rate of 110% (along with rapid growth from surviving sellers) despite what is a high churn rate in the SMB market overall ... Square’s fastest-growing segment by [gross payment volume] is in the >$500K category, which in Q3/15 increased 104% y/y vs. the micro merchant category’s 34% y/y increase."
    • Stifel's Scott Devitt is also optimistic about Square Capital and SaaS offerings, but isn't a fan of Square's valuation. "At approximately 5.5x 2017 EV/net revenues, SQ trades alongside high-growth Internet peers but above alternative payments companies, such as PayPal, Lending Club, and OnDeck. SQ also trades above merchant acquirers with the exception of Vantiv, which trades at approximately 6.7x 2017 net revenues."
    • Shares are now up 36% from November's $9 IPO price.
    • Last month: Dorsey talks up Square's growth prospects
     
     
     
     
    | 2:57 PM | 8 Comments
  • WMB

    Williams, Energy Transfer agree not to seal proposed deal before March 18

    • Williams Cos. (WMB -3.9%) and Energy Transfer Equity (ETE -4.1%) say have entered into a timing agreement with the FTC not to consummate the proposed acquisition before March 18, or prior to 60 days after substantial compliance with the FTC's second request for additional information and documentary material.
    • ETE announced in September it had agreed to acquire Williams in a deal valued at ~$37.7B, including the assumption of debt and other liabilities.
    • Also: WPZ -0.3%, ETP -4.1%.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:49 PM | 19 Comments
  • SNAK

    Inventure Foods on the move after D.A. Davidson endorses

    • Inventure Foods (NASDAQ:SNAK) jumps 4.6% after D.A. Davidson initiates coverage with a Buy rating from Neutral.
    • The investment firm sets a price target of $10.
    • Inventure trades at $7.10, on the low end its 52-week range of $6.57 to $13.10.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:43 PM | 3 Comments
  • BTU

    Paris climate deal sinks coal stocks

    • Coal stocks sink (KOL -1.7%) as renewable energy stocks rally following this weekend's climate change accord reached in Paris, which could foreshadow tougher worldwide regulations on coal and oil companies.
    • The details of implementation will be left to individual nations, with a range of possible policy measures which could include tighter environmental regulations, taxes on carbon, and a shifting of government subsidies; analysts generally believe the net impact will be a further gradual reduction of global oil and coal demand growth over the decades to some, rather than an immediate downward revision.
    • Among coal focused stocks: BTU -12.4%, CLD -10.8%, WLB -9.3%, CLF -5.2%, ARLP -4.4%, ACI +1.2%.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:25 PM | 63 Comments
  • QCOM

    Qualcomm -2.3%; company reportedly leans against split, MS cuts iPhone forecast

    • Bloomberg reports Qualcomm's (NASDAQ:QCOM) board will meet in the coming days (and possibly announce a decision by week's end) to determine whether to split the company's chip division (QCT) from its IP licensing division (QTL), a move activist Jana Partners has urged the company to consider. Management is said to be "leaning toward keeping the company together."
    • Qualcomm announced in July (along with major job cuts) it would explore a breakup and other strategic options. Since then, president Derek Aberle has suggested his company isn't crazy about the idea. QCT creates IP that's later licensed by QTL, while QTL's licensing efforts help keep QCT's royalty expenses down (due to cross-licensing deals).
    • Separately, Morgan Stanley's Katy Huberty has cut her iPhone shipment forecasts in response to new checks. She now expects iPhone sales to drop 3% in calendar 2016 and 6% in Apple's FY16 (ends Sep. '16).
    • Qualcomm has sold off, but less so than some other Apple suppliers.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:22 PM | 14 Comments
  • NLSN

    BMO Capital reiterates Buy on Nielsen after investor day

    • A investor day has BMO Capital Markets still bullish on Nielsen Holdings (NLSN -2.5%), still trailing the broader market today.
    • The firm reiterated an Outperform rating and $53 price target, implying near-20% upside from its current price of $44.32.
    • On Friday, Nielsen had reiterated its 2015 guidance and gave an initial look at 2016: revenue growing 4-6% in constant currency, 50-70 basis points in EBITDA margin expansion and EPS of $2.83-$2.93.
    • The EPS guidance is in line with Capital IQ consensus of $2.88, vs. BMO's estimate of $2.97.
    • Nielsen had also boosted its share repurchase program by $500M, expecting to use most of that authorization by the end of 2017.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:20 PM
  • BP

    BP, Chevron earn analyst praise at Scotia Howard Weil

    • BP (BP -2%) is upgraded to Focus Stock with a $42 price target at Scotia Howard Weil, based on the thesis that companies that invest through the cycle, especially in the current depressed macro environment, are more likely to improve cost structure more rapidly (Briefing.com).
    • The firm says BP is one of the few companies that has continued to sanction new projects through the energy downturn, and it thinks the company has plenty of room for cost and headcount reductions based on a bloated post-Macondo headcount; it also finds BP's dividend yield above 7.5% very compelling vs. a ~4.5% historical average, and notes $30B-plus of cash on the books at the end of Q3.
    • Meanwhile, Weil rates Chevron (CVX +2.9%) at Sector Outperform with a $101 price target, now seeing CVX as the preferred U.S. play into 2016; CVX has been plagued with operational hiccups in various regions, cost overruns and delays on major projects and concerns about dividend sustainability, but the firm believes many of these overhangs will be removed as 2016 progresses.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:12 PM | 20 Comments
  • TSLA

    Solar stocks rally after climate deal struck, oil gains, Trina gets buyout offer (updated)

    • Solar stocks are posting big gains (TAN +4.8%) on a quiet day for equities after representatives of 195 countries (including the U.S. and major developing nations such as China and India) reached a deal in Paris to curb greenhouse gas emissions. Coal stocks are going in the opposite direction.
    • Also: 1) Oil prices are bouncing after trading near multi-year lows earlier today. WTI crude is up 2.2% to $36.40/barrel. 2) Trina Solar (up 11.4%) has received a preliminary going-private offer at a 21.5% premium to Friday's close.
    • U.S. firms SolarCity (SCTY +8.4%), Sunrun (RUN +13.4%), TerraForm Power (TERP +8%), and RGS Energy (RGSE +25%) are among the standouts.  Other U.S. gainers include First Solar (FSLR +4.6%), SunPower (SPWR +6.5%) and Vivint (VSLR +2.8%). First Solar tumbled last week in response to its 2016 guidance; SunPower was hit by a $400M convertible offering.
    • Among non-U.S. names, gainers include Canadian Solar (CSIQ +4.4%), Yingli (YGE +2.9%), ReneSola (SOL +3.8%), and China Sunergy (CSUN +3.9%). SolarEdge (SEDG +4.6%), based in Israel but with strong U.S. exposure, is also doing well.
    • Update: Also possibly helping the group: Congressional Democrats are reportedly open to a deal to lift an oil-export ban in exchange for extending solar and wind tax credits.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:41 PM | 53 Comments
  • SWKS

    SWKS, QRVO, INVN slump after Morgan Stanley forecasts iPhone sales drop

    • Apple suppliers Skyworks (SWKS -5.3%), Qorvo (QRVO -6.2%), and InvenSense (INVN -4.4%) are off sharply after Morgan Stanley's Katy Huberty (a long-time Apple bull) forecast iPhone unit sales will drop 3% in calendar 2016 (and 6% in FY16, which ends in September) in response to recent checks. She also respectively cut her calendar Q4 and Q1 iPhone shipment forecasts by 5M and 9M to 74M and 52M. Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) itself is down 1.6%.
    • Huberty blames smartphone saturation in developed markets and (presumably due to forex) higher iPhone prices in emerging markets. Her remarks come amid news Apple has cut the price of the iPhone 5S by 43% in India to Rs 24,999 ($370). The company may be looking to clear inventory ahead of the launch of a 4" iPhone 6C.
    • Other suppliers such as Qualcomm, Cirrus Logic, Avago, NXP, and Synaptics are seeing more moderate declines; the Nasdaq is nearly flat. iPhone suppliers also sold off last month after Credit Suisse reported of iPhone component order cuts.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:06 PM | 30 Comments
  • AOBC

    Gun stocks higher as Sandy Hook anniversary increases the spotlight

    • Smith & Wesson (SWHC +1%) set a new all-time high of $23.95 today as investors continue to pile into the stock.
    • The rally coincides with gun control groups renewing their calls for legislation today on the three-year anniversary of the Sandy Hook school shooting.
    • Congress has been hesitant to enact any new gun laws, including a recent proposal to ban firearms to people on government lists suspected of having ties to terrorism. Most analysts think the status quo will hold until at least the next round of elections.
    • Sturm Ruger (RGR +1.3%) is also higher on the day, but is short of its 52-week high.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:04 PM | 9 Comments
  • RIO

    FT: Rio Tinto set for $4B financing deal for Mongolia mine

    • Rio Tinto (RIO -1.1%) is set to seal a project finance deal of at least $4B to expand the Oyu Tolgoi mine in Mongolia despite the commodities downturn, Financial Times reports.
    • The project finance deal is expected to be announced this week following years of delays amid disputes between Rio and Mongolia’s government over how to share costs and profits from the project, according to the report.
    • A deal would be one of the last steps remaining before Rio’s board is expected to to press ahead with expansion of the mine, which would cost a further $5B and would move the mine into a bigger underground phase; approval is now expected in 2016.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:58 PM | 1 Comment

  • Midday Gainers / Losers

    • Gainers: NRX +69%. FXCM +30%. BPMX +23%. KTOV +14%. MBII +13%. ACY +12%. EHIC +12%. TSL +11%. BCOR +11%. PBYI +11%.
    • Losers: PN -27%. ATRA -24%. ATV -20%. GPRO -16%. BIND -16%. ACRX -15%. OAKS -15%. TROX -15%. AMID -14%. MX -14%.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:44 PM

  • Stocks reverse higher along with oil

    • As low as $34.50 earlier in the session, crude oil (USO +1.5%) has rebounded back to $36.31 per barrel, bringing the energy sector (XLE +0.4%) and broader stock market (SPY +0.1%) along with it.
    • The major junk bond ETFs have about halved earlier 2% losses.
    • Money is pouring out of Treasurys, with the 10-year yield climbing all the way to 2.22% from 2.12%. TLT -1.45%, TBT +2.9%
     
     
     
     
    | 12:32 PM | 24 Comments
  • MTCH

    Match Group slumps after IPO underwriters launch coverage

    • Five out of seven analysts launching coverage on Match Group (MTCH -2.3%) on underwriter coverage day (Barclays, BMO, Cowen, Deutsche, and Oppenheimer) have assigned bullish ratings. JPMorgan has launched at Neutral, and Goldman at Sell.
    • Barclays' Chris Merwin ($17 target): "Online dating has been around since the 90s, and since that time we believe The Match Group - and its growing portfolio of brands - has been the undisputed leader." He admits the mobile shift has led to challenges in converting free users to paid ones - core revenue is expected to be flat in 2015 - but sees mobile headwinds subsiding now that 70% of new registrations are on mobile.
    • Meanwhile, he sees EBITDA margin rising to 34% in 2016 and 37.4% in 2017 from 27% in 2015. "Even as the mobile transition has caused cost of revenue to increase from iOS and Android platform fees, sales & marketing expense has fallen due to viral user growth on Tinder - and we expect that will continue."
    • Cowen's John Blackledge ($18 target) is upbeat about Tinder, and joins Merwin in arguing core Match's mobile monetization will improve as subscription friction points are eliminated. "Tinder is a key growth driver for Match accounting for ~6% of Dating revenue in ’15 but forecast to rise to ~22% by ’20. Additionally, there could be upside to forecasts depending on product, execution and advertising contribution ... we forecast Tinder subs rising from 855K ending 2015 to 2.46MM ending 2018."
    • Goldman's Heath Terry ($12 target) questions Match's ability to maintain its current dominance. "[U]ltimately we believe dating as a category has natural scale limitations that drive fragmentation over time, and in our view Match Group’s growth reflects that.” He observes that 46M of the 51M users Match added over the last four years came from either Tinder (24M) or acquisitions (22M).
    • Shares remain $1.51 above last month's $12 IPO price.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:31 PM | 1 Comment
  • DWDP

    DuPont downgraded to Hold from Buy at Jefferies

    • DuPont (DD -3.2%) is downgraded to Hold from Buy with a $75 price target at Jefferies, which expects the stock to be stuck in a rut following the announcement of its plan to merge with Dow Chemical (DOW -3.8%).
    • The firm expects DD’s shares now will be driven less by agriculture newsflow and more by details relating to cost synergies, levers to deliver growth synergies and risks to Dow’s petrochemical chain margins.
    • Jefferies expects the merger to result in the creation of a strong player in agrichemicals, seeds and agronomy, and petrochemicals, and an innovator in industrial biotech and nutrition, but that integration and end-market risks are likely to restrict the value of DD’s shares through late 2016.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:27 PM | 9 Comments
  • BPMX

    BioPharmX up again today on potential acne treatment

    • Thinly traded nano cap BioPharmX (BPMX +26.7%) follows through on Friday's up move. Shares are up 94% since Thursday.
    • Friday morning, the company announced encouraging research data for BPX-01 that was presented at the American Society of Cell Biology annual meeting in San Diego, CA. The findings showed that BPX-01's unique formulation of minocycline may represent a breakthrough in acne treatment because it can safely deliver the antibiotic to the layer of skin where acne develops.
    • BPX-01 is a stable non-oil-based topical gel will fully solubilized minocycline, the most commonly prescribed oral antibiotic for the skin condition. High doses of oral minocycline are associated with unwanted side effects that discourage compliance so a topical formulation can potentially overcome this limitation. In animal models and in vitro human skin, the application of BPX-01 delivered minocycline to the epidermis and pilosebaceous unit (structure around the hair follicle) where acne begins. No adverse side effects were observed for all doses investigated. The research also showed that the hydrophilic BPX-01 formulation distributes evenly, is not sticky and does not occlude or irritate the skin.

  • MNOV

    MediciNova's MN-166 slows rate of decline in ALS patients in mid-stage study; shares up 6% premarket

    • Thinly traded micro cap MediciNova (NASDAQ:MNOV) is up 6% premarket on light volume in response to its announcement of positive interim results from a Phase 2 clinical trial assessing MN-166 (ibudilast) in patients with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). The data were presented at the 26th International Symposium on ALS/MND (motor neuron disease) in Orlando, FL.
    • The primary efficacy endpoint of the study was safety and tolerability of MN-166, administered with riluzole, compared to placebo. Secondary endpoints included efficacy measures of functional activity, respiratory function, muscle strength and non-invasive ventilation, all compared to placebo.
    • The interim analysis included 36 ALS patients, including 33 who completed six months of treatment with MN-166. For some reason, the company reports the efficacy data in combination with placebo instead of comparing it to placebo. For example, the rate of decline in the ALSFRS-R score (a measure of functional impairment) from baseline to month 6 for MN-166 and placebo combined was below the rates observed on other ALS studies as was slow vital capacity (a measure of respiratory function). The results could not have been statistically significant for the MN-166 cohort.
    • Non-invasive ventilation utilization was lower in the study participants (appears to include placebo) when compared to a sample of patients with vital capacity greater than 60% predicted (inclusion criterion for the trial), although the difference fell short of statistical significance (p=0.07).
    • According to clinicaltrials.gov, the estimated final data collection date for the primary endpoint is June 2016. The estimated study completion date is December 2016.
    • Previously: Ibudilast Phase 2 study fully enrolled; randomization to be completed in 4 - 6 weeks (May 7)

  • AKBA

    Akebia and Mitsubishi Tanabe ink collaboration deal for vadadustat in Asia; Akebia up 24% premarket

    • Thinly traded micro cap Akebia Therapeutics (NASDAQ:AKBA) and Mitsubishi Tanabe Pharma (OTCPK:MTZPY)(OTCPK:MTZXF)(MTZXY) enter into a collaboration agreement that grants Mitsubishi exclusive development and commercialization rights to Akebia's lead product candidate, vadadustat (AKB-6548), in Japan and 22 other countries in Asia (excluding China).
    • Under the terms of the agreement, Mitsubishi will make payments up to $100M to fund the vadadustat global Phase 3 program, including $40M upfront. Akebia is eligible to receive up to $250M in additional milestones and tiered royalties from low teens up to 20%.
    • The companies will form a joint steering committee to oversee development and commercialization activities. The contract will be in effect on a country-by-country basis until the later of the expiration of the last-to-expire patent in the particular country, the expiration of marketing or regulatory exclusivity in the particular country or ten years after the first commercial sale of vadadustat in the particular country.
    • Vadadustat is an inhibitor of hypoxia inducible factor (HIF)-prolyl hydroxylase, an enzyme that promotes the breakdown of HIF proteins. HIF is the primary regulator of the production of red blood cells. The body's natural response to anemia is to increase the level of HIF proteins. It is being developed for the treatment of anemia related to chronic kidney disease.
    • Akebia is up 24% premarket on light volume.
    • Previously: Akebia set to begin Phase 3 development of lead product candidate vadadustat (Oct. 6)

  • ATRA

    Atara Bio's peptide-antibody combo flunks mid-stage PEW study; shares down 26% premarket

    • Thinly traded small cap Atara Biotherapeutics (NASDAQ:ATRA) slumps 26% premarket on light volume in response to its announcement that a Phase 2 clinical trial assessing its product candidate for the treatment of protein energy wasting (PEW) in patients with end stage renal disease, PINTA 745, failed to achieve its primary efficacy endpoint.
    • The primary outcome measure was percent change from baseline in Lean Body Mass as measured by dual energy X-ray absorptiometry at week 12 following treatment with PINTA 745.
    • PINTA 745 also failed to improve physical function, measures of glycemic control and inflammation markers.
    • Based on the results, the company has decided to suspend further development of the product.
    • PINTA 745 is a peptibody, a peptide-antibody combination. It binds to and blocks growth factors in the TGF-beta pathway, which is involved in many cellular processes. Specifically, it targets myostatin, a regulator of tissue development that can affect inflammation and muscle tissue maintenance.
    • PEW is a state of inflammation, malnutrition and muscle wasting that increases morbidity and mortality in patients with chronic kidney disease undergoing hemodialysis.
     
     
     
     
    | 7:10 AM | 4 Comments
